propositions.text: The narrator wishes to define the events that have transformed him from an ordinary person into his current state over the past few years.
These events are complex and obscure, making it difficult to define them.
The narrator feels these experiences are like a nightmare he does not want to wake from, but he realizes he must continue to experience it.
The story begins with an event in Maba Town, Jiangsu and Anhui border, specifically in a place called Ma'an.
This event is described as a strange occurrence that happened before the founding of New China.
Ma'an was historically a place with many Qin and Han dynasty tombs, attracting tomb robbers.
Ma Pingchuan, a local rich man controlling the opium trade, lived there for generations.
Ma Pingchuan had amassed a local armed force by recruiting and arming soldiers during times of war.
The Ma family's ancestral graves were located on a graveyard hill behind Ma'an village.
Many people were assigned to guard the graves to prevent tomb robbing.
One night, a strange event occurred on this graveyard hill.
Hundreds of acres of crops surrounding the graveyard, centered on the hill, withered and died overnight.
This caused great panic in the village.
Ma Pingchuan suspected a problem with his ancestral graves' feng shui and consulted several famous feng shui masters.
Despite their efforts, no explanation was found.
Ma Pingchuan decided to relocate the graves to a new, auspicious location.
The relocation involved significant effort and rituals, with cannons firing and ceremonies performed.
Upon opening the ancestral graves, they discovered that the coffins were missing, even after digging over ten meters deep.
Ma Pingchuan was furious and ordered all ancestral graves to be opened.
They found that all the graves they had worshipped for centuries had no coffins underneath.
Ma Pingchuan had the gravekeepers shot and ordered all graves in the county to be dug up to check for missing coffins.
He was determined to find out what happened, suspecting elaborate tomb robbing.
A thorough investigation revealed that all the graves without coffins were concentrated in the area where the crops had withered.
This mystery became an obsession for Ma Pingchuan.
Feng shui masters fled, fearing involvement, while others came to take a risk.
After a month of frustration and deception, Ma Pingchuan ordered all visitors turned away.
On the third day of being closed off, a child appeared sitting on Ma Pingchuan's roof eaves.
The child was about ten years old, dressed in a blue cloth gown, and looked at Ma Pingchuan without speaking.
Ma Pingchuan, already sensitive to strange occurrences, suspected supernatural intervention.
The child's presence was inexplicable given the strict security of the compound.
Upon closer inspection, Ma Pingchuan realized the child was a living person.
Intrigued, Ma Pingchuan questioned the child.
The child pointed in a direction, which Ma Pingchuan later realized was towards the graveyard.
The child then stated, "I know where your coffins have gone."
Ma Pingchuan was annoyed by the topic but intrigued by the child's words.
The child offered to reveal the location of the coffins, stating he could take money if he wished, but only wanted to tell Ma Pingchuan.
Ma Pingchuan, recognizing the child's unusual nature, softened his demeanor and asked for the location.
The child suggested they go to the graveyard together to prove it.
Ma Pingchuan, accompanied by guards, rode with the child to the graveyard.
The child pointed to the withered area and asked Ma Pingchuan what it looked like.
A guard climbed a tree and reported that the withered area resembled a scorpion.
Ma Pingchuan was shocked and climbed the tree himself to confirm the scorpion shape.
The child explained that a giant object was buried beneath the ground, and the withered area was its "shadow."
He further revealed that the graveyard was built on top of a Han Dynasty tomb, with a scorpion-shaped underground palace.
The crops withered due to a mechanism within the tomb releasing poisonous gas.
When asked how he knew this, the child declared, "Because I am that tomb robber."
The child stated that the coffins had been "eaten" by the tomb.
He explained that the coffins would be found stuck to the outer walls of the scorpion-shaped tomb.
The child warned that the area would become barren for decades and its inhabitants would suffer misfortune.
He asked Ma Pingchuan for assistance: seven days of provisions, a six-jin short sword, oil, and charcoal powder to rescue his trapped companions and seal the tomb.
He also requested that the withered area be bordered by bamboo poles filled with lime, driven into the ground.
The child explained this was to "draw a prison" and trap the dangerous entity beneath.
He gave Ma Pingchuan a letter to be sent to the Zhang family in the Northeast if he did not return in seven days, and advised that future generations should avoid the area.
Ma Pingchuan, motivated by potential treasure, agreed to help.
Ma Pingchuan prepared the requested items, and the child disappeared into the night.
The next day, Ma Pingchuan organized the villagers to set up the bamboo poles.
Ma Pingchuan planned to capture the child later and force him to reveal treasures.
Ma Pingchuan never saw the child again.
Half a month later, Ma Pingchuan ordered the graveyard to be dug up to reveal the tomb.
They found a large pit, but instead of a tomb, a two-zhang long black iron scorpion was unearthed.
Further digging caused collapses, and due to external interference, Ma Pingchuan had the pit refilled.
Ten years later, an investigation of the Zhang family's address revealed an abandoned mansion, with locals saying the Zhang family had mysteriously disappeared.
The narrator speculates the child was surnamed Zhang and would have become a remarkable person if he survived.
Chen Xuehan, after demobilization, came to Tibet and stayed for over a year, then three years in Medog.
He found reasons to stay in Tibet once he adapted to its difficulties.
His understanding of Tibet was limited to his observations, and his reason for staying was simply habit.
Chen Xuehan believed describing Tibet in writing was missing the point.
He was drawn to Tibet itself, not its concept or legends.
His reasons for being there were in the crisp air, the snow mountains, and the serene wilderness, not in grand tales.
He initially earned a living by doing odd jobs for tourists.
In Medog, he opened a small restaurant serving soldiers' families and border guards.
For eight months of the year, Medog was snowed in, leading to few customers and prolonged periods of solitude that Chen Xuehan cherished.
This desire for seclusion might stem from a childhood dream of standing peacefully on a snowy peak.
However, one winter was an exception to his peaceful solitude.
On a morning after three days of heavy snowfall, Chen Xuehan saw a lama standing at his door.
The lama was from Jila Monastery, named Zhaji, whom Chen Xuehan knew from before.
Zhaji had clearly descended the mountain overnight in dangerous conditions, suggesting an urgent matter.
Zhaji, exhausted, asked for food and stated he needed to go to Mapu Monastery.
Chen Xuehan was surprised, as traveling over Duoxiongla Mountain in that season was extremely dangerous due to avalanches.
He invited Zhaji inside, gave him food, and asked if something had happened at the monastery.
Zhaji, after asking for more wine, explained that "guests" had arrived, and he needed to inform Mapu Monastery.
Chen Xuehan found this peculiar, as it was unlikely for tourists to be in Medog at that time, and any significant activity would have been known.
Zhaji clarified that the guests were not from outside the mountains, but "from within the snowy mountains."
Chen Xuehan noted Zhaji's unusual accent, suggesting he was a foreigner.
He understood that the lama's words might have a deeper, obscure meaning.
Chen Xuehan helped Zhaji pack and accompanied him for a distance as a form of spiritual practice.
As they parted, Zhaji smiled and expressed confidence in his journey, showing an unusual sense of peace and joy.
After walking a few steps, Zhaji turned back and said something Chen Xuehan didn't understand, which was lost in the snow.
The two events, separated by vast distances, involved extraordinary secrets with an unknown connection.
This connection might unravel the greatest mysteries in Chinese history.
The narrator resumes writing because of unexpected developments in the story.
These developments have provided significant information, though not as dramatic as anticipated.
The narrator learned that some mysteries and truths reveal themselves over time after events have settled.
He likens this to finding something you weren't looking for once you stop searching.
Following these events, the narrator experienced a period of depression and indecision.
He contemplated alternative life paths and realized that ignorance can sometimes be preferable to knowledge.
Despite his low mood, he motivated himself to continue working.
He managed his uncle's shop alone after Panzi's death, finding strength in Panzi's dying song: "Little Third Master must move forward, Little Third Master cannot retreat."
He diligently worked in the business, considering it a debt to many people.
By the second quarter of the second year, he had organized many things and discovered a principle: once a system is complete and has moved beyond initial accumulation, it becomes simpler.
This allows for mistakes and course corrections, and as long as overall profit exceeds loss, the system can survive.
He also began to grasp his uncle's business acumen.
By the third quarter, he had replaced less suitable employees with those better suited to his needs.
While not as successful as his uncle, the business ran smoothly.
Seeing the steady cash flow, the narrator gained confidence in his abilities, realizing success was achievable with the right methods.
After developing traditional channels, he began visiting old acquaintances, starting with Xiao Hua.
Xiao Hua was still recuperating in the hospital, and the narrator had neglected his recovery due to his own struggles.
Xiu Xiu was caring for Xiao Hua, and the narrator's visits were also influenced by her, as she was deeply affected by Granny Huo's passing.
The narrator had learned from managing his uncle's shop that facing pain with courage and allowing it to process was crucial.
After several visits, Xiu Xiu became more comfortable with the narrator.
He spent time in Beijing helping Xiao Hua with family matters.
His influence through his uncle's connections in the south gave him more leverage to help others.
Once everything was in order, he discussed past events with Xiao Hua and his companions.
He revealed details from Zhang Family Ancient Building, including Tibetan ornaments and two rings found in a coffin, and the final story of Mute Bottle.
Xiao Hua was deeply moved and expressed a rare sense of weariness with the ongoing mysteries, having endured much hardship since childhood.
The narrator showed Xiao Hua the Tibetan-style jewelry from the coffin, and drew those he couldn't bring.
Xiao Hua identified them as Tibetan Buddhist ornaments, suggesting the coffin's owner had an interest in Tibetan culture, but nothing more definitive.
The narrator argued that burial items often hold significance, similar to how a black gold ancient knife would be buried with Mute Bottle.
Xiao Hua speculated the owner might have Tibetan ancestry or spent significant time in Tibetan regions.
The narrator suggested that the prominent Zhang family's activities in Tibet wouldn't be surprising.
He emphasized that the commonality of the jewelry didn't diminish the potential for clues in the choice of burial items.
Xiao Hua, perhaps seeing the narrator's persistent curiosity as unusual, didn't object to further investigation.
They examined the jewelry, noting its large size, rough craftsmanship, and traditional Tibetan auspicious symbols, some even belonging to Bon religion.
They noticed a peculiar red bead embedded in the necklaces, distinct from typical red materials like agate or coral.
Xiu Xiu identified the stone as a rare organic gemstone, a mineral with metallic components, commonly called moonstone.
The narrator realized this was the same stone used in the mechanisms of Zhang Family Ancient Building.
Xiu Xiu explained that the stone was ideal for micro-engraving, as its toughness allowed for clear, tiny inscriptions.
The narrator examined the bead and found no visible markings.
Xiu Xiu pointed out that information was often engraved around the perforation, which appeared rough but could hide intricate carvings.
Using her phone with a magnification app, they discovered a pattern: a scorpion, tail to head.
The narrator questioned the scorpion symbolism, considering astrological possibilities but also its traditional meanings in Chinese and Tibetan culture.
The pattern appeared to be a fusion of Han and Tibetan cultural elements.
Xiao Hua seemed unsurprised by this single clue, considering it a miracle.
The narrator consulted experts about the scorpion motif, receiving conflicting and unhelpful information.
Xiao Hua suggested it might be a coincidence, as collectors like the Zhang family might not even be aware of such details on their possessions.
Despite the uncertainty, the narrator felt it was a breakthrough.
Xiao Hua offered support by publicizing the magnified scorpion image, offering a high reward for anyone with relevant information.
The narrator returned to Hangzhou to manage his business while awaiting results.
Despite increasing income and business success, a sense of desolation persisted.
His own shop's finances were separate and struggling, sometimes requiring funds from his uncle's business.
He enjoyed spending time in his shop, listening to the radio, and contemplating matters, feeling like his true self there.
Outside the shop, he felt like a composite of other people, living a life that wasn't his own.
One pleasant afternoon, while resting in his cool room, he heard a knock at the door.
He called out for Wang Meng, who was asleep, and went to answer the door himself.
He saw a familiar figure: an old man with a mouth full of gold teeth.
Recognizing the man as the one who had changed his destiny years ago, he was shocked.
He immediately woke Wang Meng and ordered him to drive the old man away.
The old man, Big Gold Tooth, spoke to the narrator, mentioning their long separation and unchanged temper.
The narrator confronted him, blaming him for ruining his life and causing the deaths of his family's heroes.
Big Gold Tooth dismissed the accusation and claimed to have important information.
He offered a "token of trust" - a mobile phone, similar to one Xiao Hua used.
The phone contained a message from Xiao Hua, indicating Big Gold Tooth had come due to a newspaper advertisement and seemed to have important clues.
Xiao Hua advised the narrator to listen to Big Gold Tooth and that he would come to discuss it soon.
Feeling compelled to respect Xiao Hua's recommendation, the narrator reluctantly agreed to hear Big Gold Tooth out.
He calmed himself and asked Big Gold Tooth to be brief, assuming Xiao Hua had already compensated him.
Big Gold Tooth stated he was there to compensate out of guilt and mentioned the scorpion from the newspaper advertisement.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured into chapters, each detailing different events and narrative threads. It begins with a personal reflection, moves into historical anecdotes (first event) and a more contemporary mysterious encounter (second event), then delves into the investigation of clues linking these events. Finally, it shifts to the narrator's personal growth and a dramatic reappearance of a key character.
